title: Monthly Wages and Salaries Survey

list: On average it takes ten minutes to complete once you have collected the information.
Data should relate to all sites in England, Scotland and Wales.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

content.description: View the survey information and questions before you start the survey (external link)
You will need to indicate each of the pay patterns that are used to pay employees. For example weekly, fortnightly, calendar monthly, four weekly or five weekly.
You will need the following information for all of your selected pay patterns:
If the last week of the month is affected by holidays please use a more representative week

list: all employees in Great Britain (England, Scotland and Wales), both full and part-time, who received pay in the relevant period
all trainees or apprentices that were paid through your payroll for the relevant period
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
voluntary employee contributions to, and annual profit from, profit related pay schemes
any redundancy pay and pay in lieu of notice payments
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employer’s NI and contribution to pension schemes
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
benefits employees received through pay, for example, family working tax credit
expenses payments for attending meetings, for example, councillors

content.description: Calendar monthly, four weekly and five weekly pay

list: voluntary employee contributions to, and annual profit from, profit related pay schemes
any redundancy pay and pay in lieu of notice payments
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employer’s NI and contribution to pension schemes
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
benefits employees received through pay, for example, family working tax credit
expenses payments for attending meetings, for example, councillors

questions.question: Holiday pay, pay awards and bonuses

list: employer's NI and contribution to pension schemes
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business's GB payroll
benefits employees received through pay, for example, family working tax credit
expenses payments for attending meetings, for example, councillors

questions.question: Significant changes to pay or number of employees

list: You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
The data from your business is essential as it helps us measure the increase of wages over time.

questions.title: How frequently are employees paid?
questions.description: You will be asked to provide information for each of the selected pay patterns.

answers.label: Select all that apply:

questions.title: Are these all of the pay patterns used?

options.label: No, I would like to change the pay patterns
options.value: No, I would like to change the pay patterns

values: No, I would like to change the pay patterns

blocks.title: Weekly pay
blocks.description:
This section covers employees who are paid weekly.

You will be asked for the:

  • number of weekly paid employees
  • holiday pay, pay awards and bonuses paid to weekly paid employees
  • significant changes to the pay or number of weekly paid employees

questions.title: What was the number of weekly paid employees paid in the last week of {{ metadata['period_str'] }}?
questions.description: If the last week of the month is affected by holidays please use a more representative week.

list: all employees in Great Britain (England, Scotland and Wales), both full and part-time, who received pay in the relevant period
all trainees or apprentices that were paid through your payroll for the relevant period
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll

answers.label: Total number of weekly paid employees

questions.title: What was the total gross weekly pay paid to employees in the last week of {{ metadata['period_str'] }}?

list: voluntary employee contributions to, and annual profit from, profit related pay schemes
any redundancy pay and pay in lieu of notice payments (taxable and non-taxable)
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employer’s NI and contribution to pension schemes
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
expenses payments for attending meetings or training courses

answers.label: Total gross weekly pay

questions.title: The total gross weekly pay paid to employees in the last week of {{ metadata['period_str'] }} was £0, is this correct?

options.label: No, I need to change this
options.value: No, I need to change this

values: No, I need to change this

questions.title: Of the {{ format_currency(answers['answerc50e5990-5933-456a-bdc9-4cc0a02ca02d'], 'GBP') }} paid to weekly paid employees in the last week of {{ metadata['period_str'] }}, what other amounts were paid?

answers.label: Holiday pay, paid in advance
Arrears of pay owing to pay awards
Bonuses, commissions or annual profit from profit-related pay schemes

questions.title: Did any significant changes occur to the total pay or number of weekly paid employees?

list: changes in the number of temporary staff

definitions.title: What we mean by 'a significant change'

content.description: This is dependent on your own interpretation of whether there has been a significant change in the business’s figures compared with the previous month.
Also consider whether there has been a significant change from the same month in the previous year.

questions.title: What were the reasons for the changes to the total pay or number of weekly paid employees?

answers.label: Select all that apply:

questions.title: If your business has new pay rates, what is the percentage increase?

answers.label: Percentage increase of new pay rates
If your figures are backdated, which date did they begin?
What was the number of weekly paid employees who received this new pay rate?

questions.title: What were the changes to the total pay or number of weekly paid employees?

answers.label: Comments
